article-meta.issue-title: Special Research Forum: Social Issues in Management Division Dissertation Award Competition for 2011

body.p: Business & Society (BAS) appears quarterly in March, June, September, and December. This December issue completes Volume 51. This journal began publication in September 1960, founded at Roosevelt University. BAS is sponsored by the International Association for Business and Society (IABS). As of December 2009, Business & Society was added to the Social Sciences Citation Index (SSCI) ®. A greatly enlarged, globally representative editorial board supports the journal. About a dozen associate editors are presently at work, specializing by key areas of business and society scholarship. The editor expresses appreciation here for the collective efforts during the past year of all associate editors, editorial board members, reviewers, and authors.

All new regular manuscript submissions to BAS should go directly to its online website at http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/bas. Proposals and other communications concerning this journal should go to the editor, Professor Duane Windsor, at odw@rice.edu. Current calls for special issues of BAS are posted regularly at http://iabs.net and http://bas.sagepub.com/.

sec.title: From the Editor
sec.p: December 2012 contains a special dissertation forum and three research articles, which broadly concern aspects of stakeholder theory. The three finalists for the best dissertation award of the Social Issues in Management (SIM) division of the Academy of Management in August 2011 prepared abstracts of their dissertations and also a brief reflection essay on their experiences in preparing dissertations. Dr. K. Praveen Parboteeah, University of Wisconsin–Whitewater, chair of the dissertation award committee, has provided an introductory essay for the forum, which appears at the end of this issue. The abstracts represent the doctoral dissertations, in alphabetical order, of Dr. Darline Augustine (PhD, London School of Economics), Dr. Joel Marcus (PhD, Wilfrid Laurier University), and Dr. Judith Schrempf (Université de Lausanne). Dr. Augustine was winner of the 2011 award.

The first research article, by Edward T. Walker, of the University of California, Los Angeles, concerns “Putting a Face on the Issue: Corporate Stakeholder Mobilization in Professional Grassroots Lobbying Campaigns.” The study investigates the expanded influence of stakeholders on the strategies, legitimacy, and competitiveness of firms. Using a unique, original data source, the author assesses the determinants of adoption of grassroots lobbying by a firm. The most significant factor is the firm’s degree of inside lobbying, reflecting that politically active firms diversify sources of influence.

The second research article, by Christian Frankel and Erik Højbjerg, of the Copenhagen Business School, is entitled “The Political Standardizer.” The article provides a framework for demonstrating that corporate technical activity and corporate political activity can overlap substantially or intertwine in ways that prove quite difficult to tease apart analytically. A “political standardizer” is a company that uses technical standardization as a political strategy. The article provides an interesting case study of Lego, the Danish toy producer.

The third research article, by James Weber and Kathryn A. Marley, Duquesne University, is titled “In Search of Stakeholder Salience: Exploring Corporate Social and Sustainability Reports.” The article draws on the stakeholder salience framework (power, legitimacy, and urgency) to study the web of business–stakeholder relationships involved in the Fortune Global 100’s corporate social responsibility and sustainability reports.
